B. You must start baking the first cake 5 hours and 15 minutes before the party (estimate)

Knowing that the room is symmetrical and allows for perfect placement of the spotlights, how many spotlights are needed to illuminate all four sculptures?
A. Only one spotlight is needed
B. Only one spotlight is needed?
C. Only one spotlight is needed (estimate)
D. Only one spotlight is needed.

there are four sculptures placed at the four corners

The spotlights must shine directly downwards
The spotlights cannot overlap in their paths of light
Each sculpture can only be lit by one spotlight
The room is symmetrical and allows for perfect placement of the spotlights

After some thought, one clever student argues that following this logic, the test can't be on Thursday either, because come Wednesday night, without a test, Thursday would be the only remaining option, ceasing to be a surprise. Continuing this deduction, she concludes the test can't be on Wednesday... Tuesday... or even Monday! However, to the students' shock, the test was indeed given during the next week and it still was a surprise. How could this be, and when was the test given?

One clever student deduces that the test can't be on Thursday either.
The student argues that come Wednesday night, without a test, Thursday would be the only remaining option, ceasing to be a surprise.

The test was given during the next week and it still was a surprise.

Imagine you are in a game show where you have to split 100 gold coins among five crew members of a pirate ship, including yourself, according to the following rules: The members' ranking from highest to lowest is Captain, First Mate, Quartermaster, Boatswain, and Cabin Boy. What is the most gold coins you can keep while still surviving, assuming the rest of the crew members are perfectly logical and greedy (trying to get as many gold coins as they can), and everyone knows each other's rank and intentions?

In a strange land, there are three types of trees, each of which bear a unique fruit once every year. One day, a child decides to collect fruits by moving in a straight line, starting from a corner of the rectangular grid. The child picks fruits from the first two trees along the path and notes the sequence. It's a 'plum' from a Plumtree followed by an 'apple' from an Appletree. Assuming the grid contains at least three rows and three columns of trees, what type of fruit will the child collect from the third tree that lies on the child's straight path?
